data.text: Alternatives to Schwalbe Marathons for Puncture Protection

Hi All So I've already had a puncture after my first ride out on my newly built bike. Covered a whopping 16 miles! Off to France for a week's riding next month so I need to replace the tyres with something a little more dependable. I know the Schwallbe Marathons are the go to touring bike tyre. I was just wondering what alternatives there are ? I would like something that can handle varied terrain. Let me know if you have any recommendations. Thanks

I had the same issue with Gravelking slicks- I was recommended the Teravail Ramparts (also come in tan wall) and couldn‚Äôt be happier. I run them tubeless and get 4-5000 miles out of my tires with minimal upkeep- for comparison, I only ever got 1,000mi max out of the Gravelkings. That‚Äôs just if you want slicks, though- I don‚Äôt have a specific recommendation for knobby tires.
data.author: Carl Sanman

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon Plus Tour. Why look for inferior alternatives.
data.author: Robin Symonds

data.text: because I'll also be using the bike on surfaces other than pavement

data.text: my 1st few trips to rhe nearby bike trails at cannock chase I did while on marathon plus tyres. They're were surprisingly very good

data.text: Can they be setup Tubeless?

data.text: I've used marathon plus on gravel roads riding a tandem. No problems... and no punctures
data.author: Huw Thomas

data.text: The Plus Tour has more tread than the Plus, and is designed for a variety of surfaces, it's not just for road. We have toured with them for months at a time across Europe on all sorts of unpaved surfaces.
data.author: Robin Symonds

data.text: I've gone with the Big Ben plus Green guard. Seems to have good puncture protection and is 2.0 wide. Did look at the marathon tour plus but was unable to find anything wider than 1.5. Appreciate your help.
data.author: Thomas Jenner

data.text: Marathon Plus Tour, fully loaded and gravel roads, 2 punctures (thorns) in 5000 k. üëç
data.author: Jos Callens

data.text: Good choice. I like folding tyres (I don‚Äôt think you can get the Big Ben Plus that way) and more tread, so prefer Marathon Mondials. Same puncture rating as BBPs, and lighter than the Plus Tours.

data.text: Kenda and IRC is what I use and have never had a puncture. Knock on wood

data.text: Take a look at the Schwalbe Hurricane.

data.text: I'm running tubes, the tiniest piece of what I can only assume was glass.

data.text: You can try more tires and then end up with Schwalbe Marathons, or you can buy Schwalbe Marathons right away.

data.text: Done 20,000km in 2020 with Marathon Plus (2 sets) on a variety of surfaces, plenty of dirt and gravel. Find them the best for the area I live in and its prickles and thorns.

data.text: Schwann Marathon Plus! Why not? They come in virtually every size!

data.text: If you ask by specific brand name, you‚Äôre going to get different opinions

data.text: I find the Continental Contact Plus has nice traction and rolls easier than heavier tires like the schwalb

data.text: Marathon Plus?
data.author: Nuj Simon

data.text: Have a look at reviews for Schwalbe Land Cruiser tyres. About ‚Ç¨10 each, hundreds of reviews, multi terrain, 5 out of 7 on Schwalbes puncture protection chart.
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: Please don't jump from superlight and supple tyre to the other end of spectrum and get a marathon which is a super heavy and hard tyre. The feeling fron the ride will be completely ruined. Fixing a flat from time to time is not a huge problem. If it's just for the tour, then maybe ok, but there are plenty of tyres in the middle, which are still supple but with some level of protection. I swear by Continental Speedride for gravel, or something smoother like Marathon Racer for the road, but people here have already suggested plenty other good tyres, so choose what is available.
data.author: Ondrej Pok

data.text: If it's a new bike, make sure the rim tape is good and properly fitted and didn't cause the puncture.
data.author: Simeon Pang

data.text: If you like the tan walls you could get Tannus Armour inserts. These can be ridden at low pressures if off road. Very unlikely to get a flat and if you do they can still be ridden although not quite as well.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Where are you going to in France. I live in Castelmaurou.
data.author: Kabalino Nivrap

data.text: Unlucky. If you have decent tyres it could literally be bad luck, if they are cheap that's a possibility. Do you run high enough pressures I ride at4.2 bar 700/28 hardly get punctures, though I've bought gel filled tubes to fit next time I need totake a tyre off
data.author: John Axson

data.text: I have also built myself a bike for touring with a similar gearing set up (but with a electric motor). I have a bike with Marathons on, no punctured tyres ever, got another with Gator skins ditto. But for the new build I have gone for Hutchinson gravel tyres which had a tube puncture within 150 miles bit which are way more comfy. Have made them tubeless now and will stick with.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: If you have tubes, you can get sponge tape that sticks to the inside of the tyre to reduce punctures.
data.author: Simon Thompson

data.text: Thanks for all your help I've gone with Schwallbe Big Ben's with the green guard. Once back from France I'll stick the Panaracers back on.
data.author: Thomas Jenner

data.text: Thomas Jenner your panaracers are tubeless compatible. I'd definitely convert. Could be as easy as gorilla tape. What did you ride over that caused the puncture? Do you normally ride in the lane of traffic? Or near the edge where the sharp things are? How likely is this problem to recur? A weeklong tour is a great time to set up tubeless. People don't always realize, but with sealant in the place of tubes, the tires need to spin. Especially when first set up. so pump them up and ride them, every day, and you'll have a well sealed, puncture resistant system after a few rides. Of course you'll still risk going flat after a number of months of disuse.
data.author: Christopher Avery Maxfield Camp

data.text: WTB venture
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Best tires you can get are Continentals just add a bottle of slime half in each tube and punctures will be part of history for you.

data.text: Continental has less rolling resistance as Schwalbe, this resulting a higher overall speed and/or less effort. Puncture resistance is just one factor, consider also the weight of the tire;

data.text: Not a good idea to tour straight-off on a new bike. Best to get any bugs sorted with plenty of local miles first!
data.author: Jon Moore

data.text: I became seriously hacked off from punctures with the same Gravelking tyres, and switched to Marathon Green Guard which, as others say, are pretty 'firm' to say the least. I've bought a pair of Gravelking Semi Slick Plus. Not fitted yet but according to the Rolling Resistance test website they have good punture resistance. Heavier than the slick Gravelkings but nowhere near as heavy as the Marathons. That said, I've had no punctures with them!
data.author: Eamonn Keenan

data.text: specialized armadillo if you can find some. if shwalbe, go for marathon PRO version. bullet proof, only downside is they get bit slippy on wet surface or loose gravel.
data.author: Adam Jakistam

data.text: The bigger and thicker the tyre, the less chance of punctures. You can spend (lots) more on puncture resistant racing tyres (23/25/28c), but in the 32c+ range you‚Äôre entering big and thick territory, and frames with clearance for bulkier tyres. If you care about rolling resistance, weight and performance, you can spend loads on a thinner tyre with better puncture resistance, but‚Ä¶ you get the picture. üôÇ Nice cassette. What you running?
data.author: Tim Holman

data.text: I've done 5000km with my Marathons without a puncture. üëå
data.author: Karen Hagan

data.text: Mudguards would be good too, after my first tour with a wet bum and back , I fitted good quality guards ,safe riding.
data.author: David Brown
